title: Measuring the Robustness of Audio Deepfake Detectors
author: Xiang Li (Fordham University), Pin-Yu Chen (IBM Research), Wenqi Wei (Fordham University), ...
relevance_why: This paper discusses the robustness of audio deepfake detection models against various perturbations, which is directly related to audio processing and could inform future improvements in audio quality enhancement techniques.
background: Evaluating how well audio deepfake detection models perform under different types of audio perturbations, including noise, modification, and compression, to ensure reliability in real-world scenarios.
contribution: This paper introduces a systematic evaluation framework for audio deepfake detection models against a variety of common audio corruptions, demonstrating the varying levels of robustness among different model architectures.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Most existing methods focus on improving detection accuracy without assessing robustness against practical audio distortions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work highlights specific vulnerabilities in detection models related to audio modifications and compression, which have not been comprehensively addressed previously.

key_innovation: Systematic evaluation of audio deepfake detectors against diverse audio corruptions and the demonstration that larger foundation models provide more robust detection capabilities.
real_world_impact: The findings underscore the need for robust audio deepfake detection frameworks, informing developers on how to improve model reliability in real-world applications where audio corruption is common.

new_terms.Equal Error Rate (EER): **Equal Error Rate (EER)** is a metric in binary classification that measures the rate of false positives and false negatives, allowing comparison of model performance at a specific threshold.
new_terms.Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR): **Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR)** is a measure of signal power relative to the noise power, indicating audio quality.
new_terms.ViSQOL: **ViSQOL** is an audio quality assessment metric that simulates human hearing to evaluate the perceptual quality of audio signals.
